articles.headline: Clerk in Kentucky Chooses Jail Over Deal on Same-Sex Marriage
articles.snippet: Kim Davis of Rowan County rejected a proposal that would have allowed her deputies to grant same-sex marriage licenses. Had she consented, a federal judge would have considered releasing her from jail.
articles.abstract: Kim Davis of Rowan County rejected a proposal that would have allowed her deputies to grant same-sex marriage licenses. Had she consented, a federal judge would have considered releasing her from jail.
articles.lead_paragraph: ASHLAND, Ky. — A Kentucky county clerk who has become a symbol of religious opposition to same-sex marriage  was jailed Thursday after defying a federal court order to issue licenses to gay couples.
articles.byline: By Alan Blinder and Tamar Lewin

articles.headline: Silicon Valley, Seeking Diversity, Focuses on Blacks
articles.snippet: The acute underrepresentation of blacks in the technology industry has given rise to a flurry of initiatives in Silicon Valley to improve the situation.
articles.abstract: The acute underrepresentation of blacks in the technology industry has given rise to a flurry of initiatives in Silicon Valley to improve the situation.
articles.lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — More than a decade before diversity became a hot issue in Silicon Valley, Jason Young came home on winter break from Harvard to discover that his family was being evicted.

articles.headline: Hedge Funds Faced a Test in August, and Faltered
articles.snippet: Hedge funds aim to reap high returns while countering volatility in stocks, but during the global turmoil in August, many just extended their history of underperformance.
articles.abstract: Hedge funds aim to reap high returns while countering volatility in stocks, but during the global turmoil in August, many just extended their history of underperformance.
articles.lead_paragraph: A surge in volatility. Plunging global stock markets. A surprise Chinese currency devaluation.

articles.headline: Philip Falcone, Former Head of Vast Fund, Tries a 3rd Act
articles.snippet: His latest effort, HC2 Holdings, faces hurdles because of his history with regulators, and his first comeback has had lackluster results, but he remains undeterred.
articles.abstract: His latest effort, HC2 Holdings, faces hurdles because of his history with regulators, and his first comeback has had lackluster results, but he remains undeterred.
articles.lead_paragraph: Philip A. Falcone, the brash hedge fund titan who once managed $26 billion before stumbling and running afoul of regulators, is pressing ahead on a new comeback effort, his second.

articles.headline: Friendship Between Putin and Xi Becomes Strained as Economies Falter
articles.snippet: Slowdowns in Russia and China have put energy deals between the countries in question, affecting the once-vaunted relationship between the two leaders.
articles.abstract: Slowdowns in Russia and China have put energy deals between the countries in question, affecting the once-vaunted relationship between the two leaders.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — They have met more than a dozen times and stood shoulder to shoulder during Thursday’s military parade here. But the once-vaunted relationship between the Chinese president, Xi Jinping, and Russia’s leader, Vladimir V. Putin, has come under strain as the economies of their countries have faltered.
articles.byline: By Jane Perlez and Neil MacFarquhar

articles.headline: Indian Automaker Tata Aims to Restore Jaguar’s Cachet in U.S.
articles.snippet: Sales of Jaguar, the British brand acquired in 2008 from Ford by Tata, along with Land Rover, have been lagging this year.
articles.abstract: Sales of Jaguar, the British brand acquired in 2008 from Ford by Tata, along with Land Rover, have been lagging this year.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT — When Tata Motors of India acquired the Jaguar and Land Rover brands in 2008, the deal added a new twist to the rapid globalization of the auto industry.

articles.headline: Exodus of Syrians Highlights Political Failure of the West
articles.snippet: Little has been done in Western capitals to stop or mitigate the slow-motion disaster that was befalling Syrian civilians and sending them on the run.
articles.abstract: Little has been done in Western capitals to stop or mitigate the slow-motion disaster that was befalling Syrian civilians and sending them on the run.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Arresting images of desperation on the West’s doorstep have brought Syria, for the moment, back to worldwide attention: refugees cramming into train stations and climbing border fences; drowned Syrian toddlers washing up on beaches, a girl in polka dots, a boy in tiny shoes.

articles.headline: Jobs Report Gives Ammunition to Both Sides of Fed Rate Debate
articles.snippet: As the Federal Reserve weighs raising interest rates, it must contend with both good news and bad news from the August numbers.
articles.abstract: As the Federal Reserve weighs raising interest rates, it must contend with both good news and bad news from the August numbers.
articles.lead_paragraph: Despite disappointing job growth last month, the unemployment rate fell to its lowest level since early 2008, sharpening the debate within the Federal Reserve over whether to raise interest rates when policy makers meet in two weeks.
articles.byline: By Nelson D. Schwartz and Binyamin Appelbaum

articles.headline: Migrants Cross Austria Border From Hungary
articles.snippet: After thousands embarked on a 300-mile march toward Germany on Friday, the government retreated from enforcing European immigration restrictions.
articles.abstract: After thousands embarked on a 300-mile march toward Germany on Friday, the government retreated from enforcing European immigration restrictions.
articles.lead_paragraph: NICKELSDORF, Austria — Thousands of migrants who have been bottled up in Hungary, demanding passage to the West, will be allowed into Austria and Germany, the Austrian chancellor said late Friday. Early Saturday, the first buses carrying them arrived at the Hungary-Austria border.
articles.byline: By Alison Smale, Rick Lyman and Anemona Hartocollis

articles.headline: Stephen Schwarzman of Blackstone Feels the Agony of Victory
articles.snippet: Few firms have scooped up as much money in so short a time as the Blackstone Group. Maybe that’s why the C.E.O. takes its stock price personally.
articles.abstract: Few firms have scooped up as much money in so short a time as the Blackstone Group. Maybe that’s why the C.E.O. takes its stock price personally.
articles.lead_paragraph: Stephen A. Schwarzman ought to be a satisfied man.

articles.headline: A Positive Jobs Report Keeps the Fed in a Tricky Spot
articles.snippet: With the latest labor figures neither much better nor much worse than expected, the Federal Reserve has a tough call on whether to raise rates.
articles.abstract: With the latest labor figures neither much better nor much worse than expected, the Federal Reserve has a tough call on whether to raise rates.
articles.lead_paragraph: The latest numbers on the job market, which the government released Friday morning, are good pretty much all around. But that is not really a surprise; the jobs numbers have been consistently good for at least the last year.

articles.headline: With a Revamped Apple TV, Company Hopes to Camp in Your Home
articles.snippet: At Apple’s product event on Wednesday, it is expected to introduce a TV device with more capabilities as the company seeks a bigger presence in homes.
articles.abstract: At Apple’s product event on Wednesday, it is expected to introduce a TV device with more capabilities as the company seeks a bigger presence in homes.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Apple is finally getting serious about pushing into our living rooms.
articles.byline: By Katie Benner and Brian X. Chen
